Yes, this is already handled at [1]. As it states there:

 > If a new image is provided on rebuild, we will need to run
 > through the scheduler again, but we want the instance to be
 > rebuilt on the same host it's already on.

Since we're in the else case, we already know that 'host' is unset which means, based on [1], we definitely have a different image.

In terms of RPC versioning, we don't support N -> N-M, where M > 1, so we can be sure that change I34ffaf285718059b55f90e812b57f1e11d566c6f which made that check at [1] mandatory is present.

config.yaml.message: Is there any concern that anyone is already using the old config option?
Not as far as I can tell.  The old config option was not working anyway, so if it was set, it would have had no effect.
Did you ensure removal of default behaves as expected? I've typically seen an empty "default: " specified instead.
Yes this works fine here.  `default:` and omitting the default key results in the same behaviour.  :)
It sounds like you might have tested this successfully. If it works I don't see a problem with it. I think the other openstack charms use 'default: ' and that is probably just to be explicit.

Please correct me if I'm wrong here... it's not really documented at https://juju.is/docs/sdk/config#heading--configuration-specification

According to the source, it _appears_ that `default:`, `default: null`, and omitting the default key will result in the same output from the config-get command ( https://github.com/juju/juju/blob/b1d97bb7758b563f74d626eab124560b7c2a4b2f/worker/uniter/runner/jujuc/config-get.go#L69-L71 ).  And the charm-helpers hookenv.config() function loads from this command: https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/blob/4dae9ccf5850c906cd72133310675f100dd17762/charmhelpers/core/hookenv.py#L440-L448

Either way, it's what we want in this charm, because the keys won't be present in an iteration over the config dictionary if not set, which makes things simpler in the code.

As an aside, I'm pretty worried when I see things like `default: None`, which I reckon results from this weak typing + yaml + not explicit docs.  (this results in the literal string "None". An example at https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-keystone/src/commit/a76a3d9599edaf33b8b9f18f7136006524e868e5/config.yaml#L215-L217  ...

It took me a while to convince myself that the 's3api.backend_path' key would always be in the environ.

In s3request.py, at first glance, it looks like s3api.backend_path is only set for a successful response [1], and here we're dealing with a 404 (NoSuchKey). I still wonder if it might be defensive to check if 's3api.backend_path' in req.environ

   """Create a MonkeyPatch.
        :param name: The fully qualified object name to override.
        :param new_value: A value to set the name to. If set to
            MonkeyPatch.delete the attribute will be deleted.
        During setup the name will be deleted or assigned the requested value,
        and this will be restored in cleanUp.
        When patching methods, the call signature of name should be a subset
        of the parameters which can be used to call new_value.
        For instance.
        >>> class T:
        ...     def method(self, arg1):
        ...         pass
        >>> class N:
        ...     @staticmethod
        ...     def newmethod(arg1):
        ...         pass
        Patching N.newmethod on top of T.method and then calling T().method(1)
        will not work because they do not have compatible call signatures -
        self will be passed to newmethod because the callable (N.newmethod)
        is placed onto T as a regular function. This allows capturing all the
        supplied parameters while still consulting local state in your
        new_value.

Thanks for the explanation, I see what you mean.

I am not sure that this approach would actually solve the problem we are having. It assumes that before the object quota is synced between the different Ceph units, the objects would also not show up in `list_container_objects`. This may or may not be true, but it's worth the try.

I will do some experimentation with it.

This is specifically a problem we run into when using HA ceph as storage backend. With HA ceph, you can upload more objects than the quota as long as you do it within to time where the quota syncs. More context is in [0] and [1].

Regarding your question, I'm sure how a waiter for `create_object` could be used in this case, can you elaborate on that?. Ceph would not remove the object again after the quote is synced, so keeping track of the objects would not give us the right information.

An alternative approach would be to temporarily reduce the quota sync to, say, 1 second and reverse it at the end of the test. But that could introduce some problems on a production cloud.

The ceph quota sync interval is set by the operator, the default is 600 seconds. [0] has some more information under the `Quota Cache` header. I think we can retrieve the quota sync interval through the radosgw cli, but I thought a tempest config would suffice.

I assume that we can see the object data of all the ceph units before the quota is synced, though it is possible that this is not the case and your suggested approach works. It is also possible that listing the objects will force a quota sync, in which case your suggestion also works.

sushy/connector.py.message:
I think that is likely better, in the grand scheme of things.

The Redfish spec document says the BMC shall respond with a 406 if it cannot handle a non-compressed response.... And if the header is omitted, it *should* not respond with compressed contents. Sending identity should force us into an specific pattern of behavior.

def delete_distributed_port_binding_if_stale(context, binding, port_id):
    if not binding.router_id and binding.status == n_const.PORT_STATUS_DOWN:
        with db_api.context_manager.writer.using(context):
            LOG.debug("Distributed port: Deleting binding %s", binding)
            context.session.delete(binding)
            for bindlv in (context.session.query(models.PortBindingLevel).
                      filter_by(port_id=port_id, host=binding.host)):
                context.session.delete(bindlv)
            LOG.debug("For port %(port_id)s, host %(host)s, "
                      "cleared binding levels",
                      {'port_id': port_id,
                       'host': binding.host})

            bind['router_id'] = router_id or None
            bind.update(bind)

Right, good appreciation. This is needed both in check in L1347 and L1353. It is needed to have one and only one compute responsible of this resource provider. This is why we store the chassis that have reported this RP:

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Greetings!

I've taken time to review the overall changes, and I'm a little worried this is a bit over complicated as it is introducing several different options. It is attempting to use "irmc_verify_ca" as a strictly True/False boolean field, when the general approach which has been taken in python-requests and other places where it is used, is to have the boolean, and also allow it to be the CA certificates information source.

The code, internally also duplicates this behavior in advance of providing it through, and then adds additional validation calls, which really may not be needed if things are kept consistent with how other drivers handle CA certificate source data.

Heading down the path of simplifying, would remove a lot of the added code into common.py.

Additionally, I think it would be fair/acceptable to just default the value to true for the patch to land on master branch. If you source from the [default]webserver_verify_ca option, then it would be true by default and in backport that could potentially just be switched to false for non-breaking behavior.

Finally, this patch introduces two verify steps, which are not backportable, and I'd prefer to see as separate patches, as we will mainly want to backport this patch in a form which requires minimal changes from version to version in the process of backporting.

Based upon the path taken, the commit message, docs, and release note will also need to be adjusted accordingly.

If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out.
I appreciate you taking time to review. I followed your recommendations and modified patch.

ironic/conf/irmc.py.message:
I'd prefer that we keep this consistent with other drivers:

[ilo]verify_ca - https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/conf/ilo.py#L84

However I think that is also a somewhat outdated style since there are a few different ways to handle it. In fact, I think ilo is the only driver which has a driver level override in ironic.conf, and given the trend of operators wishing to avoid configuration files... it might be best to avoid it for this as well.

The prevailing trend also seems to be less ironic.conf level settings, and more API settable options given dynamic environments:

https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/drivers/modules/ibmc/utils.py#L47

https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/utils.py#L63

https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/drivers/modules/ilo/common.py#L62


The overall base pattern seems to be rooted in https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/configuration/config.html#DEFAULT.webserver_verify_ca


Specifically, I think we might want to forego an ironic.conf file option, and perhaps lean on the [DEFAULT]webserver_verify_ca option as a base default.

I'd also consider following the triple option behavior generally used for simplicty.

nova/pci/whitelist.py.message:
this I think is wrong

its a string not a list

I think the confusion here is because we allow the whitelist to both be a mutltiStrOpt filed and each filed can contain a json list of values

so the input type of the whitelist_sepc is a json encoded string but
that json string can contain a list of whitelists.

so the data type should be str, but we can parse multiple device specs form it

look at _parse_white_list_from_config[1] where the value is used, it iterates the value like:

    for jsonspec in whitelists:
    
so if 'whitelists' would be string then jsonspec would be char in each iteration.


Also if you look at the oslo.config MultiOpt defined[2] as:

    Multi opt values are typed opts which may be specified multiple times.
    The opt value is a list containing all the values specified.
    
So a MultiOpt is always a list. 

Our special handling for the whitelist / device_spec is in _parse_white_list_from_config where we check if each item in that list (provided by oslo) is dict or a list[3]. If it is a list then we do one more round of iteration on that list and expect that there can only be dict now. This is how we can handle both a json encoded list of dicts, or simply a list of json encoded dicts. :) I know it is crazy.

Bottom line. I think the type hint here is correct per the oslo doc and our usage of the value.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/bcb96f362ab12e297f125daa5189fb66345b4976/nova/pci/whitelist.py#L61
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.config/blob/9eaae044534cbe015217019781c4c0d97f0402df/oslo_config/cfg.py#L1229-L1230
[3] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/bcb96f362ab12e297f125daa5189fb66345b4976/nova/pci/whitelist.py#L63-L74

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Whether accidental or not, it did prevent us from merging changes that would break when running against an existing zuul_console server (which is what happens on static nodes; the process never dies).  Would it be worth adding an explicit test with the old behavior for that?
PS 7 has modified this to run against both the zuul_console from the executor and the one from the zuul checkout.

Actually, that brings me back to the initial problem.

When I changed the name of the streaming file name in I199313e1fff567b176020ced1d8e92c5059012cd, it was not working because the command.py would write it out to "zuul-console-*" but the extant zuul_console process was looking for "console-*".

So I'm not sure it's valid to test command.py from the Zuul checkout against executor's version of zuul_console, as they share assumptions?
I guess we can run it without the port override to talk to talk to the executors version.  It feels like a bit of an abstraction breaker.  I'll propose in a follow-on to keep the idea separate

I wrote a bit about this on https://review.opendev.org/850270 but in short, zuul_console runs forever on static nodes, and also serves multiple jobs at once.  Making an interface change between it and the console plugin (or callback plugin) should take that into account.  This job failing was (accidentally?) showing us that problem.

playbooks/zuul-stream/fixtures/test-stre.message:
It's definitely not meant to be configurable.

There will still be times that files will be left behind (for instance, when a job is aborted).

If you really want to ensure proper cleanup, perhaps the console streaming daemon could act as a tmp reaper.  That might obviate the need for the protocol complexity (but it's nice to have a protocol anyway).

While reviewing how this all fits together I notice that we don't seem to expose the console log port as an option via the executor server command? The internal class object accepts the console port as an argument but nothing every sets it so we always use the default.

Not sure if we want to try and expose that better? Or maybe those bits are just there to make testing simpler.

There is not much reference of it in the docs, which I might try to improve.  source/howtos/nodepool_static.rst is the only place i can see that refers to port 19885, but also says the static node requires python 2, so :)

Part of the reason I wanted to take this approach was so that we didn't have to have documentation explaining why there are files left behind that need to be dealt with.

This is discussed now in the follow-on https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/851942/2

I'd like to come back to the reaper idea when we have the protocol in place, so that we can do things like make the names of the output files less generic

    | member_ids | []                                   |
    | name       | sg-foo                               |
    | policy     | anti-affinity                        |
    | project_id | 781c9299e68d4b7c80ef52712889647f     |
    | rules      | [{'max_server_per_host': 2}]         |
    | user_id    | baf52ddd09934580b845e3c936cbc7f9     |
    +------------+--------------------------------------+

You'll also note you've dropped the mapping of 'member_ids' -> 'members'. You don't want to do this. There are other issues with other microversions.

Before:

    ❯ export OS_COMPUTE_API_VERSION=2.15
    ❯ openstack server group create sg-foo --policy soft-affinity
    +------------+--------------------------------------+
    | Field      | Value                                |
    +------------+--------------------------------------+
    | id         | 90d622b2-386f-436c-8cc3-ce7bce6fe7f4 |
    | members    |                                      |
    | name       | sg-foo                               |
    | policies   | soft-affinity                        |
    | project_id | 781c9299e68d4b7c80ef52712889647f     |
    | user_id    | baf52ddd09934580b845e3c936cbc7f9     |
    +------------+--------------------------------------+

After:

    ❯ export OS_COMPUTE_API_VERSION=2.15
    ❯ openstack server group create sg-foo --policy soft-affinity
    +------------+--------------------------------------+
    | Field      | Value                                |
    +------------+--------------------------------------+
    | id         | b1bdb06a-7108-494b-9220-4c56c975fbd0 |
    | member_ids | []                                   |
    | name       | sg-foo                               |
    | policies   | ['soft-affinity']                    |
    | project_id | 781c9299e68d4b7c80ef52712889647f     |
    | rules      | None                                 |
    | user_id    | baf52ddd09934580b845e3c936cbc7f9     |
    +------------+--------------------------------------+

Clearly 'rules' should not be emitted here. You probably want a microversion-specific check to ignore this column if present, similar to what you did for policy/policies above.

You don't want 'get_server_group' here. A 'get_foo' proxy method will only retrieve a resource by its ID. You also need to retrieve it by its name so you can do things like:

    ❯ openstack server group delete sg01

The 'find_foo' proxy methods ('find_server_group' in this case) will attempt to retrieve by ID and will fall back to retrieving by name if this fails. You want this functionality. If you don't, the following happens:

    ❯ openstack server group delete sg-foo
    No ServerGroup found for sg-foo: Client Error for url: http://10.0.108.84/compute/v2.1/os-server-groups/sg-foo, Instance group sg-foo could not be found.
You don't want to drop formatters here either...
Just remove this. What you've done is fine

Thanks Mark. As you know that 'aptly' does not support parallel accessing, When package A is built done and its '.deb' binaries are uploading to the repository 'deb-local-build', the meta file of the repository like 'http://stx-stx-repomgr:80/Packages' will disappear for a while until the new one generated after aptly's publishing operations done, during the time, package B is fetching the repository 'deb-local-build' to get the depended packages, it fails to run 'apt-get' command on 'deb-local-build', to resolve this race condition, the static config item 'deb [trusted=yes] http://stx-stx-repomgr:80/deb-local-build bullseye main' here is replaced with the dynamic snapshot in sbuild command like:
sbuild --extra-repository='deb [trusted=yes] http://stx-stx-repomgr:80/deb-local-build-2 bullseye main'
This should be captured in the commit log.

Should the max parallel jobs or chroots be parameterized? e.g: --parallel 10
Is this the maximum jobs that can be run in the same chroot in parallel?

This is used to limit the number of jobs in 'make -j<jobs>' for one package. The original value of the jobs is equal to 'os.environ.get('MAX_CPUS')' which is the maximum number of cpus that container allocates. If there are 10 parallel build tasks, and each task takes '10' jobs simultaneously, then the total jobs are 10*10 = 100.

I will repeat my reply from other patch also here: I don't agree with that point. IMO those constants should be in neutron-lib as they can be used by other projects as well. And also e.g. stadium projects may introduce new constants for own tables there thus having all in single place (similar like api-def) will help to keep it sane. See e.g. BAGPIPE_FLOOD_TO_TUN_BROADCAST constant - this is perfect example of such additional table used by stadium project which is added to that list. And currently to keep this value only for this project it has to be added to neutron so networking-bagpipe project will have to depend on neutron to use it. And our goal should be to reduce such dependencies on neutron for stadium projects and keep them dependent on neutron-lib.
So IMO all those constants (especially those which defines tables) should go to neutron-lib.

And yes - if we will need to add new table, we should add it to neutron-lib. That way we can be sure that same value isn't already used e.g. by some other stadium project as all values will be in the same place always.
And doing new neutron-lib release isn't big problem. We can do it whenever we want. If You need new release, please just propose patch to releases repo or ping someone on IRC channel 😊

The current pattern accept any characters between # and HEADERS so can match variety of patterns with # and HEADER

eg.
# this is not the HEADER created by puppet

which is not really intended. Because here we intend to exclude the known problematic line, having more strict pattern to match the actual string pattern would less likely to cause unexpected match and allows us to understand the exact pattern we should exclude.

I still don't fully agree with the concern with changing the hash generation logic in master(Do we care minor update in master or do we really have any case where we expect no change in config files or container images during upgrade ?) but i that still causes huge concern to you then I'll abandon this.

> The current pattern accept any characters between # and HEADERS so can match variety of patterns with # and HEADER

We delete all commented lines "as before" and that should be fine IMO.. My point is why change the config hash unnecessarily, when it's not expected to. Having said that it's 'only' my opinion. I did not try to block it:) If others are fine with it (seems Bogdan is) we can still merge it.

> The current pattern is too much vague and is worth fixing before we find out any issue caused by it IMO.

Not sure I get what's vague about it though?:) Clearly, it deletes rows starting with HEADER comment and also removes the comment if appended to the prev line. Anyway, it's already an internal hack to generate the config. If we can do the same thing "without changing the hash" and a simpler pattern lets do it.

I agree we should avoid updating the original patch. That one needs to be backported to stable branches and if we modify the patten then the change might cause undesired container replacement.

However I really don't see any concern with updating this in master. The change does not affect any minor update in older releases and affects only upgrade from wallaby (or train if we also support FFUx2) to Zed. I don't expect any case where container images are left without being replaced during upgrade.

The current pattern is too much vague and is worth fixing before we find out any issue caused by it IMO.

Certainly - I'll still w/d this PS but, I'll put it on my list of things to do and tag you on a subsequent PS!

Hey, awesome that you're doing this! I have a couple of very old WIP (work-in-progress) that I was reminded of when I saw this patch come up. There's a regression test (feel absolutely free to adapt/reuse it!), and a "fix" patch on top.

As you can see in the review comments on https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/791553/1 and in our (Red Hat) internal bug report for this (https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1943613), the current consensus is to implement supporting changing the MTU as a new feature, and in the meantime to just continue erroring out the live migration if there's been a change in MTU, but to give a better error message to the user.

Would this approach (at least the second half of that, I'm not going to ask you to implement the new feature) work for you?
I will add a unit test soon. Just wanted to get this on the board and run through CI quickly now.

So I was thinking some more about this, and the existing error message is actually mostly OK, what sucks is that it goes all the way to actually trying the live migration. If we were to try and catch a changed MTU earlier, I *think* the best place would be where I left my inline comments.

Threw something up at: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/852367/1/nova/virt/libvirt/vif.py

This is closed and should probably remain that way to make it clear that this is not the right approach?
err, I mean withdraw the patch? If you're already improving the error message that's good for me.
oh, perfect! I was thinking along these same lines as well, but having the spot pinpointed makes this change easier.

The problem is that the MTU on Neutron ports (which is what Nova uses as its source of truth) should not be mutable until Nova implements proper support for changing it on the fly. If we take the approach of keeping the original MTU during a live migration, we end up with a split brain situation with Neutron saying one thing, and the libvirt XML saying another. That's not great. Since Neutron can't (or won't? I'm not sure of the politics here) make the MTU immutable, our next best option is to prevent operator "error" and refuse to live migrate with a new MTU.

hmm... I'm surprised that patch was rejected. We have a legitimate use case here in that we are trying to, as you say, prevent things from exploding when the underlying network MTU changes. Retaining it is perfectly fine for now, and that's great that there's progress on allowing it to change -- we just want the live-migration to not fail in such cases in the meantime...

I've tested your patch works just as well for me. The existing comment led me to believe that if the MTU is not specified, we should not add an element to the tree.

ahh, interesting, thanks for taking the time to explain! As a Calico user, I am seeing our taps plugged at the "correct" MTU after live-migration... but I can see this as being an enormous problem for the rest of the community.

Bummer, but I'll improve the error message here, instead, then.

doc/source/developer/specs/tracing.rst.message: Nit: "analysis"
I should really turn on flyspell.

Could the existing logging infrastructure be replaced by a console exporter? That is how the tracing library works in Rust, and it's quite useful because the same message are used for both console output and for opentelemetry service like jaeger.

Otherwise, isn't this spec going to duplicate the existing work done on logging?
What would be missing from the span that only appears in logs? I understand we don't want to trace low level debug messages, but shouldn't most of the important logs be part of the trace?
Thank you for the details, that makes sense to me. I hope we'll be able to consolidate telemetry and logging in the future, and starting with span sounds great.

OpenTelemetry describes a system for exporting three types of data: traces, metrics, logs.  This spec only proposes that we use the OpenTelemetry protocol to export spans, not log messages or metrics (since we already have infrastructure for the others).

OpenTelemetry spans can also have event information (which can look a little bit like a log entry from a data structure point of view, but might be rendered visually as a span with no duration).  We can associate some events with spans but we shouldn't over-use that (See the "Events and Exceptions" section in this spec).

I do think a lot of the interesting information in logs will appear in spans (request ids, etc), but it will be in a different form, so I don't think there needs to be overlap with logs.  If we say that, for example, the beginning and ending of a merge request span is redundant with the existing log entries, we're probably talking about 10-20 log invocations that would be redundant with spans out of the 1400 log invocations Zuul currently has.

It is possible that we could decide that using OpenTelemetry to export log entries instead of the python logging library, however, there are many different ways people are configuring logging right now (console, file, elasticsearch, splunk, etc) all of which we would need to continue to support, preferably without requiring any additional tooling.  I think it would be best to get some experience with OpenTelemetry for tracing before we decide to ask it to do more.

This spec says that we will only use OpenTelemetry for emitting spans, not logs; we'll continue to use the existing python logging framework for that.  I definitely don't want to duplicate log infrastructure.

(It's perfectly fine to only emit spans with Open Telemetry, and ignore the logs (and metrics) it supports.)

doc/source/developer/specs/tracing.rst.message: Is the plan for node requests to be represented here as well (at least the scheduler-side of issuing the request and then eventually receiving an assignment or not, and any reissuing)? At a minimum, being able to suss out which launcher(s) handled a request without needing to dig in the scheduler log would be nice, though if the traces also cover nodepool itself this could be even more useful.

Yes for the scheduler view of a node request as you describe.  I believe we should be able to associate the launcher that fulfilled the request (also, if we want, all the launchers that declined it) with the span.

We could also forward the span information to Nodepool so that it can open up its own spans, but I'm not anticipating that right now in this spec.  At least partly because I have another spec I'm working on that would fold Nodepool into Zuul.

If we retain Nodepool as a separate app, I expect us to extend tracing support to it eventually.  If we fold it into Zuul, we'll probably do the same.

But to keep things simple for now, let's just say this covers the "scheduler view" of a node request.
Does this mean any incomplete spans (system crash or extremely slow processing) won't be visible?

Yes, basically the protocol just sends everything at the end of a span.  So if we crash before the end of a span, it won't make it to the storage system.

However, for us, that's only true for a span that starts and ends on the same system (imagine a merge job).  Since some of our spans start and end on different systems (imagine a queue item), those would be crash-resilient since we're storing data in ZK for them.

Child spans with no parent (parent crashes but child doesn't) will be visible (they show up with warning messages in jaeger).

Is this also true for the trace ID? Usually the trace ID is what connects all the spans and you can definitely propagate the trace context (which has the trace ID) and create a new span from that.

I think a missing piece is that you can (de-)serialize a span, which we probably need.

Given a root span for a trace, you can serialize/deserialize its trace context so that other systems can make child traces from it.  But the deserialization doesn't give you the root span, it gives you the trace context for the root span, which is only useful for creating child spans, not for emitting the root span itself.  The issue is that our root spans start on one host and end on another, and there isn't a way to serialize the span itself.  Here's what we want to do:

1) Start root span on scheduler A
2) Send trace context to merger
3) Merger emits child span
4) End root span on scheduler B and emit root span

That would work if we only had one scheduler, because the root span could be kept in memory.  But with multiple schedulers, and no way to serialize/deserialize the root span, we can't transfer the root span from step 1 to step 4.  So we need to augment the SDK somehow.

We could implement span serialization ourselves, but we don't actually need to do that, all we really need is the trace id, root span id, and timestamp of when the root span started.  I guess it is a form of serialization, but it's verify lightweight (we will only store that info, and not everything else like the list of errors, logs, events, etc).

Maybe something else worth exploring is how we want to configure this. When I wrote the initial prototype there was quite some config necessary depending on which exporter was used. But maybe that's a non-issue if we only support the OLTP exporter.
Yeah, with only the OLTP exporter, it's a pretty small set of config options (just what you'd expect: host, port, maybe protocol).  I don't see us needing more than an ini section with a few options.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Here's some background info. I tripped across the problem late in the day last Friday when I did a local standalone tripleo build from master, and got this puppet-apache package:

Name         : puppet-apache
Version      : 7.0.1
Release      : 0.20220729113326.fd2360d.el9
Architecture : src
Size         : 412 k
Source       : None
Repository   : delorean-component-tripleo
Summary      : Installs, configures, and manages Apache virtual hosts, web services, and modules.
URL          : https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppetlabs-apache
License      : ASL 2.0
Description  : Installs, configures, and manages Apache virtual hosts, web services, and modules.

Notice that it's marked v7.0.1, with date code 20220729 (also Friday). This version includes the "narrow down datatypes" that broke my deployment.

Looking further, puppetlabs has not tagged a 7.0.1 release, so this is directly off their master. But this patch's unit tests are failing because our puppet-openstack-integration is pinning puppet-apache at v7.0.0 [1].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/blob/master/Puppetfile#L159

The tests fail because the puppetlabs-apache module doesn't include the "narrow down datatypes" patch, and is passing in 'false' for the access_log_XXX parameters.

BTW, it might be interesting to explore adding code to this module that basically converts null values for those parameters to undef. That might alleviate the need (at least in the short term) to update all those other openstack puppet modules that still default the parameters to False.

I'll unblock this now so that we can get the other patches.

We can consider implementing transitional logic but I'd leave it now because dealing with underlying breaking change is something out of our scope and we don't really want to bump version required for that.
This change is compatible with the existing releases (<= 7.0.0), and users should update the values according to the requirement by puppetlabs-apache.

I'll be open for this topic and am happy to discuss what we want in our modules. Even if we implement the logic, we can do it as a follow-up, I think.

Seems like the cause is that RDO pulled in puppetlabs/apache and built puppet-apache from main branch.

Anyway, this makes sense, but I understand the issue here that we might need to bump minimal puppetlabs/apache version for the default values, or people need to fix the param values they provide.

I think it makes sense to change the default values, if we 1) bump the minimum version and 2) DONT enforce the values ourselves that way we'll support both usecases but favor running something newer.

Oops. I should have reloaded the page before I post my comment.

> Anyway, this makes sense, but I understand the issue here that we might need to bump minimal puppetlabs/apache version for the default values

The new default values I'm using here are compatible with the existing versions (7.0.0 and older), and do not cause any functional change in underlying logic. puppetlabs-apache has been supporting integer priority and access_log_* set to undef and it has been behaving same manner with string priority and access_log_* set to false

The only things affected by version bump of puppetlabs-apache are the unit tests effectively asserting defaults in apache::vhost but I don't really think we want to make our unit tests compatible with all versions we support as unit tests are mostly for our development purpose.

Thanks for these inputs, Alan.

I'll take time to reconsider implementing the workaround logic here while I'm drafting the fix in a few modules.

My initial thought was that it's a kind of over-killing for us to deal with the broken compatibility in our module but it might be helpful later in case anybody tries to use stable release with newer puppetlabs-apache (as we can backport it to stable branches), as we have never declared upper version explicitly.
It sounds like we have a plan.
